Situation1: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Situation2: They encounter a situation where a friend is being treated unfairly and feel a stronger responsibility to intervene or speak up.
Story: I pushed my cleaning cart down the long hallway, the scent of disinfectant clinging to my uniform. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Every corner spotless, every surface sanitized.” I took pride in my work, knowing families depended on me to keep their homes safe. Today, though, as I entered the living room, I overheard the homeowner scolding my friend Priya, another cleaner, for a mess she hadn’t made. Priya’s eyes met mine, pleading silently. My heart pounded. As a Hindu, I was taught to stand up for dharma—for what is right. But my job demanded silence and obedience, no matter what. If I spoke up, I risked my position and the trust placed in me to maintain order and cleanliness. If I stayed quiet, I betrayed my values and my friend. The mop in my hand felt heavier as I stood there, torn between my duty to my work and my duty to my conscience, unsure which voice to follow.
